channel.title: Speedometer pls
channel.description: meh i did find some examples on google but they're all fucking dirty and i would rather understand how a speedometer works. so can anyone (bobdole, of course) explain how to make a speedometer, basically just how to find the line coordinates.

int angle = 90 - (minutes / 720) * 360

Where minutes is the number of minutes passed in the day…so midnight and noon would be 0 minutes, and six o’clock would be 360
[/quote]

To discover more of such hax, one seek the power of math

item.title: Speedometer pls
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Sorry, I must have missed that picture you posted.

The trig functions in java’s Math class use radian values, not degree values, which is why its coming out weird. You can still use degrees tho…just make sure to use Math.toRadians() before plugging into sin and cos. ALSO, you MUST use -Math.sin() (negative) as it’ll be incorrect otherwise.

Read full topic

item.title: Speedometer pls
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Right…because you have to modify the coords returned…swing doesn’t use the coordinate plane system (per se). Which is why I asked you to post some of your code…mainly the part where you draw the circle and the line.

Read full topic

@BobDole81 wrote:

Can you post some code?

item.title: Speedometer pls
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“lawl, post:3, topic:52143”][quote author=BobDole81 link=topic=73229.msg827368#msg827368 date=1169885059]
So what did you need help with?
[/quote]
how to find x+y, durr[/quote]

BobDole81:

If you know the radius of the speedometer circle, then, you can determine the points by getting x and y components: (r * cos(angle), r * sin(angle))

Read full topic

item.title: Speedometer pls
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Hmm, line coordinates…well, the easiest way would be start at the center of the (presumably) circular gauge. Obviously, it will depend where in your panel the speedometer will be, so I will suggest to write a method assuming basing the center of the speedometer at the point (0, 0) of a coordinate plane.

Then, say that 0 mph is like 225 degrees (relative to the +x axis) and the max speed (probably 120 mph in many cars) is 315 degrees (-135 degrees and -45 degrees respectively). That means for your 120 mpg range you have 270 degrees of the circular speedometer to work with.

The angle of the speedometer marker would therefore be: 225 - ((speed / 120D) * 270). If you know the radius of the speedometer circle, then, you can determine the points by getting x and y components: (r * cos(angle), r * sin(angle))

da bobdole has spoken

Read full topic
